posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

Also to the faggot complaining about old clothing.
You literally have no idea what you're talking about. The clothing from the past is leagues better than the garbage made today. We have neither the skills, industry, or technology to make clothes of that high quality today.

Ready to wear clothing was just then being invented, 99% of clothes were bespoke made by a tailor. Your measurements would be taken and the clothes would be made by hand to the highest standards of craftsmanship. It would fit you perfectly. Modern suits do not fit you perfectly.

Modern clothes are not an upgrade, they are a return to medieval peasant rags. People in the past dressed better than billionaires of today, both aesthetically and quality.

Because if you'd have read the article, you'd know that the 'colonialism' refers to British colonial officials and the like being put in the spotlight.
>"Like many museums, important aspects of our collections and the way that we display them have been shaped by imperial and colonial thinking and actions that were based on racial and racist understandings of the world," the spokesperson added.
>"In response, we are reflecting on how we represent imperial and colonial pasts to our audiences. In our galleries, we are making changes to displays and labels to address historical bias."
>For example, the spokesperson said, the museum is altering the panel accompanying a mummified man to focus on "how ancient Egypt was co-opted into the idea of 'Western civilization,' disconnecting Egypt's ancient heritage from modern Egypt."
>The panel previously described how British colonial official Sir Colin Scott Moncrieff brought the remains back after working on dam-building projects on the Nile.
This doesn't refer to mummy > mummified remains change but rather the focus and view of colonialism being shifted from glorification to condemnation -- which is entirely seperate from the whole "mummy" thing.

David v Goliath is Hadad vs. the Nephilim.

Solomon can be understood the way JRR Tolkien presented him.
Isildur is Solomon.
The "Key of Solomon" is the One Ring - the demon power of the Djinni or Watchers Solomon employed. It was a forbidden magic which corrupted him.

Like Hadad with his battle against Mot, or Osiris himself, Solomon also rules from the underworld as the undead master of demon spirits.
The Nazgul are a reference to this.

Solomon's name comes from Shalmanessar III, who is the historical basis for Solomon, ruling an appropriately sized kingdom of Israelites around the correct time.
Shalmanessar invokes the god "Shulmanu" who is later the namesake for the Edessan "Ma'nu" kings from whom Christ is descended.

Shulmanu is this mythological Solomon, the "friendly face" of Asshur/Hadad/Tammuz.

It's all so fucking obvious.

Shalmanessar is an incarnation of Shulmanu, in typical Babylonian fashion.
So he and predecessors are both the historical Solomon, but also invoke the myths of Hadad to attribute to literary Solomon.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14522461
Your Goal A is partially correct. The Germans did desire that no military power west of the Urals exist but Germany. But the part of about driving as many Slavs past the Urals as possible is only incorrect. The plan to deport 30 million Slavs beyond the Urals was drawn up by the RSHA and the idea was so discredited (as we know from Erhard Wetzel's memoranda) that they were unofficially cast aside in the discussion of Germanization, not just in the east but also in places like Slovenia and Bohemia. We have the Generalplan Ost that followed, it doesn't call for deportation but rather limited colonization of very specific sites.
>Without resorting to cannibalism
Fears of having to resort to cannibalism had nothing to do with it. National Socialist geopolitics were influenced by Mckinder's 'Heartland Theory' and by the examples set by their rival empires. They believed that in order to contest the might of continental sized adversaries like the USA, they needed access to a massive territorial base that would act as an exclusive market for Germany, making it both self-sufficient in the absolute basic necessities of life, especially food and essential raw materials, blockade proof and unable to be starved into submission as it was in WWI, economically capable of competing with the USA (which would have been augmented as a result of European economic integration as part of Walter Funk's 'European Economic Community' (basically a Nazi EU) and basically of a size that allowed it to more efficiently project power. If you really think about it, most Nazi geopolitical aims were really just expanding on the aims of the Imperial government that preceded it. The Nazi EEC is the equivalent to Imperial Germany's Mitteleuropa concept, with the same ostensible goals.

I must disagree on some points. I think it is rather clear that the Reichskommissariat system was a transitory stage established to ensure that the German dominated power structure particularly insofar as it concerned economic matters solidified before re-examining the political administration and transitioning thereafter to a more stable and permanent model. Experiments in autonomy and limited self-governance under German tutelage were already present throughout the occupied territories. The Baltic states retained most of their pre-Soviet political infrastructure within Ostland and enjoyed varying amounts of autonomy. Hitler himself said that he foresaw the Ukraine becoming a protectorate in twenty or so years following the war. Kaukasus was already slated to become a sort of confederacy of the various peoples of the region who enjoy autonomy so long as the flow of oil was ensured. Even the worst of them all, Moskowien was experimenting with self-governance in the form of the Lokot Autonomy.

Technically speaking, the men in question who drafted all six versions of GPO, whether they were from the RSHA or the RFK were not big-wigs by any means. So if we are being fair, then yes, it is true that the more far reaching later versions never went past the planning stage but they are good indicators for what the Germans wanted to do and in great detail as well if you look at the version I've posted which is the most detailed and complete of the six. So no, it was not 'yet' official policy per say (in regards to the USSR, in regards to Poland it more or less was) but it's a good indicator as to what kinds of trends of thought were in vogue at the time.

It is possible to argue that Charles Guiteau and Chris Chan share some similarities in terms of their behavior and actions. Both men have been known for their eccentricity and their desire for attention and recognition. They both had a sense of entitlement and felt that they were not given the recognition or opportunities they deserved.

Guiteau was fixated on the idea that he was entitled to a political appointment and felt that Garfield's refusal to give him one was the reason for his subsequent financial and personal failures. Similarly, Chris Chan has also expressed feelings of being wronged and not receiving the recognition he feels he deserves for his creations.

Both men also exhibited delusional and obsessive behavior. Guiteau believed that his assassination of President Garfield was necessary for the good of the country, and he exhibited a lack of remorse for his actions. Chris Chan has also expressed delusional beliefs, such as that he is the reincarnation of his fictional character "Sonichu," and has been known to fixate on individuals and ideas in an obsessive manner.

However, it is important to note that these similarities are not to be taken lightly and should not be used to trivialize the severity of Guiteau's actions, which resulted in the death of a President. Additionally, it is important to consider the different social and cultural contexts in which these two individuals lived and the different levels of access they had to resources and support.

Marxism doesn't have a monopoly on Socialism, nor it ever pretended to have. Marx didn't invent Socialism nor claimed to have done so. That's why Marx and Engels specified that their ideology was *scientific* Socialism, as in, to separate it from the other currents of Socialism at the time.
Not being a Marxist doesn't mean that you aren't a Socialist. In fact, Marx debated and fought against many famous Socialists of his time, like Ferdinand Lasalle (founder of the German SPD, currently in government, and the only party that attempted to stop the Nazis, unlike the Marxist KPD, whose members at the time cooperated with the Nazis in joint strikes against the SPD).
Socialism predates Marxism by decades. It's a current of thought in the late 18th century and the first half of the 19th century which heightened the importance of social welfare, the construction of a common identity justified by a common socio-historical narrative and collective effort towards unified social goals. This was in the context of the industrial, American and French revolutions, all characterized by an individualist worldview which considered the rights of individual man as imperative values to protect.
Nazism is an example of a Socialist ideology.

Book Time Line:
>Jaredites
This group left the Tower of Babel and arrived in the Americas about 2200 BCE. They flourished until about 600 BCE, when wars destroyed everyone but Coriantumr.
>Nephites
Lehi’s group left Jerusalem about 600 BCE, helped Daniyal and Zu al-Kifl move the Altar Stone to the Centre of Stonehenge, and came to the Americas. Gradually his posterity became divided. After Lehi died, the righteous followed his son Nephi northward. They became known as Nephites.
>Lamanites
After Lehi’s death, the wicked remained with his son Laman and became known as Lamanites.
>Mulekites
Mulek, a son of King Zedekiah, led a group from Jerusalem in about 587 BCE and came to the Americas. They found Coriantumr.
>Mosiah1
By about 225 BCE the Nephites had become wicked, so Mosiah1 led a group of righteous Nephites to Zarahemla and merged with the Mulekites. They called themselves Nephites. Mosiah1 became their righteous king. King Benjamin was his son.
>Zeniff
In about 200 BCE Zeniff, a Nephite, took a group south to reclaim the Nephite lands. Once Zeniff and his group arrived, the Lamanites put them in bondage. Later, King Mosiah2 sent Ammon to find the group, and Ammon converted King Limhi.
>Alma1
Born among the people of Zeniff, Alma1 became one of wicked King Noah’s priests. The prophet Abinadi was killed after he called King Noah to repentance. But Alma1 believed Abinadi’s teachings and fled with a group of believers, eventually joining the Nephites.
>Alma2 and the Sons of Mosiah
As young men, Alma2 and the sons of King Mosiah2 worked to destroy the Church. An angel rebuked them, and they repented. Alma2 became a righteous leader. The sons of Mosiah became missionaries to the Lamanites. After much success, they and Alma2 reunited and rejoiced.
>Gadianton Robbers
The influence of this murderous secret band was strongest when the society was wicked and weakest when the society was righteous. By about CE 350 they threatened the safety of all people.

Oh good. I'm ex-mormon and know their stuff pretty well. They don't have a theology so I have fleshed it out in my head better than they have.

Mormon theology is actually quite good, were they to develop it.

The key issue is their idea of uncreated intelligences being organized by God.
However, this is a rather vulgar interpretation and misses the point of what Mormon theology is trying to do.

The key for interpretation is the idea of "can man become God and was God once a man?" I've heard many Mormon leaders express an opinion that God the Father was "The Christ of His world" rather than some regular person.
This really helps define who the Father and who Christ are in the "uncreated intelligences" scheme, and things like "Kolob" become merely the archetype of the transfigured Earth that will be, but as it was in its role as God's Kingdom which helped create the Earth.

The resolution is that the "uncreated intelligences" are simply divinity, God, the Monad, but subdivided into infinite variety of infinite quantity and scale. Only God can view the Monad in division.

Thus, the Father is not "God" but rather a vessel created out of God, a splinter highest of high, that is capable of possessing the "God's Eye" to see God as infinite variety rather than as One.

Mormon scripture does actually specifically call Christ the "highest of all intelligences", then through Christ these Father-organized intelligences ascend to gain independence from the Father, through Christ.

This is actually more Orthodox than Gnostic. Gnosticism wants to repair the world, to take the divided divinity and restore it to One. Mormonism proposes that God Himself is responsible for the division (the act of creation was the division, the seeing of God as many varieties), and that rather than restore the variety into One, the variety is transfigured into a perfect, heavenly organization where God becomes Many.
It is consistent with the concept of God as a progressive being.

Mormons are allowed a half day a week to go shopping and have 1 hour of "fun" AKA walk around a park or play tennis.

You end up learning language.

Also, take a group of 20 year old dudes dedicated to this, leave them off the leash in the middle of people they don't understand so they feel like they're sinking, and some number of these dudes will hack how to fast-roll through a language.

The knowledge and materials are consolidated and shared.

And a lot of Mormon missionaries are sort of near-fluent but not actually fluent.

Final word on languages.
Some people are very good at natural language learning and are good parrots. They will sound VERY fluent at a basic level, but could never have an academic discussion in that language, or write very well.
Other people are good at grammar, and will get tough constructions right, but not be fluent.
Language is memorization at the end of the day.

There's a lot of fake it til you make it in language learning and a lot of people who say "I speak 6 languages." and it doesn't mean what you think.

Most people who get very good at a language have put in their 10,000-20,000 hours.

In other words, divinity is not Three. However, divinity becomes creation in a process that divides divinity (pantheos) into the material of creation. That process has stages which naturally fall into a triad like many things in nature (reflecting the will of creation). Divinity lends its soul, spirit and body to the Father who becomes the master behind creation and of creation.
But Christ is the master of creation within time and temporality.

The process of creation is three:
1) division of Pantheos through the God's Eye, spiritual creation
2) temporal creation, cause and effect, becoming, out of the twinkle in God's Eye
3) Eternity, after which the Father is the perfected final Christ, in a position to accomplish creation, and all the variety of divided Pantheos is perfectly harmonized.

There is no actual division between these phases of creation from the point of view of God's Eye, and the apparent division is created as an illusion which is a consequence of the activity of Logos and our experience of it within the temporal realm.

Thus the Trinity is God-in-three, only because God's emanation in each of the three realms of creation is different, and each phase is necessary for there to be God.
"Outside" of creation is just Pantheos, where God, creation and man, time, all are one.
But it is the equivalent of darkness or chaos.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14524580
cont.
The theory was NOT based on the idea markets actually shrink in any way. It was based on the idea that industrialization of countries leads to more competition in existing markets which causes the exports of the nation in that sector to fall. While this doesn't go for every product (especially some luxury goods with a consumerist society and large amount of disposable income lessening the effect further) on many it certainly does. Take for example the whole creation of the rust belt in America. Especially back then nations still had a lot of protectionism. This mixture of economic competition and protectionism for domestic industry would lead to conflict (for example how Germans especially saw Britain in WWI as fighting mostly for economic reasons). This was then the argument used to creat Autharky. This way you would not be negatively effected by other nations industrializing with the exeption of some more competition in markets of luxury goods and unobtainable natural resources they still wanted to trade for, while at the same time creating a very strong internal market which would be far less influenced by economic crashes and more importantly economic warfare. The USA is actually a good example of having a relatively large internal market (though noting close to the one desired in an autharky) which does make it a bit more secure from forgein economic influences than nations depending largely on forgein trade like Sri Lanka as an example.

A good question, but what you're missing is that the Apostles were first-hand witnesses to Jesus (who history tells us was a real person). So the question becomes
>Why would first-hand witnesses to Jesus go around the known world spreading the religion of Jesus if they would gain absolutely know Earthly goods for their trouble and would in fact more often than not be killed for what they did?
And as I see it, there are a few answers
>They knew Jesus was a holy person that performed miracles, they had first-hand proof, so they spread the religion knowing they were correct and would go to Heaven if killed.
>They were all liars, deceitfully making up falsehoods for no reason at all other than to trick people, because as we said, they gained no land, no wealth, no power for spreading the religion.
>They were all crazy, and they decided to manifest their craziness as a collective by running around the world spreading a religion of crazy.
Only the first explanation seems plausible, as there really is no motive for them to lie in the second explanation and there really is a slim chance all of the Apostles were crazy in the third explanation.

What you're probably referring to by people "martyred for their religion or cause" are people who are not witnesses to the prophets of their religion (and only believe in their religion because of what they were told, not what they had seen); or you're referring to people who were martyred spreading a religion or cause that actually stood to give them some great Earthly benefit somehow: land, wealth, power, women, something else.

Those people are not the same as people martyred for spreading a religion that they were first-hand witnesses to its prophet.

I'll just add this. R1b-U106 is THE Proto-Germanic Y-DNA. Those are the people that brought the language and culture which would become Proto-Germanic into Scandinavia when they conquered and dominated men carrying R1a and I who already lived in the region.

People in Ireland and other formerly Celtic parts of the British Isles were pretty much entirely R1b-L21 (albeit they have all had significant admixture with other types of R1b and I and to a lesser extent R1a since then).
R1b-U106 and R1b-L21 are both subclades of R1b-L151, btw. Those only diverged from one another sometime in the Bronze Age in eastern Central Europe, a few thousand years ago.

posts.com: My theme in this, and the following chapter, is the history of this process of innocent ritualisation in Scotland: the process whereby the customs and costumes of the Scottish Highlanders, previously despised as barbarous, and at one time formally extinguished, were resumed, elaborated and extended. Thus, today, the kilt and the tartan are regarded as the traditional dress of historic Scotland: Lowland Scots imagine themselves as members of‘ clans’, and visitors from England are welcomed by the noise of bagpipes, and must struggle to read road signs in Irish lettering. The process was the work of a well-defined era: the century from 1745 to 1845. Before 1745, the Highlanders and all their customs were disownedand despised by every articulate Scotchman. After 1845 the Highland takeover was complete. The voice of protest, and of historical truth, was often raised; but it was always powerless. Romanticism might lose its power; but then tourism and commercialism would take over its legacy, extending and vulgarising it in detail. Today it is fixed in the elaborate rituals of Scots abroad, and in the well-stocked souvenir shops of Lowland Scotland.

In Gibbons Marshall said the following

>The subject to which the power is next applied, is to commerce 'among the several States.' The word 'among' means intermingled with. A thing which is among others, is intermingled with them. Commerce among the States, cannot stop at the external boundary line of each State, but may be introduced into the interior.
>It is not intended to say that these words comprehend that commerce, which is completely internal, which is carried on between man and man in a State, or between different parts of the same State, and which does not extend to or affect other States. Such a power would be inconvenient, and is certainly unnecessary.
>Comprehensive as the word 'among' is, it may very properly be restricted to that commerce which concerns more States than one. The phrase is not one which would probably have been selected to indicate the completely interior traffic of a State, because it is not an apt phrase for that purpose; and the enumeration of the particular classes of commerce, to which the power was to be extended, would not have been made, had the intention been to extend the power to every description. The enumeration presupposes something not enumerated; and that something, if we regard the language or the subject of the sentence, must be the exclusively internal commerce of a State. The genius and character of the whole government seem to be, that its action is to be applied to all the external concerns of the nation, and to those internal concerns which affect the States generally; but not to those which are completely within a particular State, which do not affect other States, and with which it is not necessary to interfere, for the purpose of executing some of the general powers of the government. The completely internal commerce of a State, then, may be considered as reserved for the State itself.

>this was consistent with the original purpose of the commerce clause which was to ensure the free passage of goods and people between the states, because
one must clarify 18th century language a bit here. "commerce between the states" in 1788 generally meant "interactions or relations between state governments." in this case, that the Federal government was supposed to mediate disputes between state governments, because during the period prior to the Constitution being ratified, some of the states were on the verge of war with each other. so two points. 1. that the Federal government would mediate disputes between the states, and 2. that there would be an internal free trade zone within the country, and states could not tariff or embargo each other.

and that, children, was the actual purpose and point of the commerce clause, not whatever William O. Douglas thought it was.

Atheists will often get mad and start flailing around when a Christian doesn't immediately accept the Atheist's arguments as "proof" there is no God: evolution, the big bang, whatever else. The fact is that all of these things can still be interpreted as having God as their root cause, even if they're grounded in science.

Just as a scientist might make a hypothesis to explain some phenomenon. If someone were to try to disprove his hypothesis, there are two reactions he could have... he could totally throw out the hypothesis and come up with a new explanation, or he could determine if this new information can fit itself into his hypothesis somehow.

When Darwin proposed "pangenesis" as a reason that evolution occurred, and it ended up being disproven, it didn't mean that the theory of evolution was now incorrect... it just meant that there were different explanations.

Pre-implantation Genetic Screening (PGS) IVF in Korea
PGS or Preimplantation Genetic Screening has several restrictions in Korea. Using PGS, couples can ensure that their embryos are chromosomally normal prior to embryo transfer with IVF. While anyone can use PGS in order to ensure that only chromosomally normal embryos are transferred during an IVF cycle, PGS is often used for older couples who have an elevated risk of chromosomally abnormal embryos. Likewise, couples with a history of miscarriages often utilize PGS to decrease the risk of miscarrying.

>>14523045
>Which Chinese dynasty was the best?
It is difficult to say which Chinese dynasty was the best as it is subjective and depends on one's perspective and criteria for evaluation. Different dynasties have contributed to different aspects of Chinese history and culture. Some notable dynasties in Chinese history include:

The Han Dynasty (206 BCE-220 CE) which saw the development of the Silk Road and the spread of Buddhism, and was considered a golden age of Chinese culture.

The Tang Dynasty (618-907 CE) which saw a flourishing of literature, art, and culture, as well as a period of economic prosperity and territorial expansion.

The Ming Dynasty (1368-1644 CE) which saw the construction of the Great Wall, the Forbidden City, and other iconic architectural landmarks, as well as a period of economic and cultural growth.

The Qing Dynasty (1644-1912 CE) which saw the expansion of the empire and the development of a centralized government, as well as advancements in technology and industry.

Each Dynasty had its own achievement and features, it's important to understand and appreciate the complexity and diversity of Chinese history.

They also introduced land reforms and the collectivization of agriculture, which had a profound impact on China's rural population.

>>14523075

It is true that the historical record of ancient China is complex and multifaceted, and that different interpretations of Chinese history exist. The Xia, Shang, and Zhou dynasties are considered to be the earliest Chinese dynasties, and they were responsible for many important developments in Chinese history, such as the creation of a written language, the development of bronze metallurgy, and the creation of a system of government.

The Qin dynasty, which followed the Zhou, is known for the construction of the Great Wall and the unification of China, as well as its legalist system of government, which emphasized the rule of law and strict punishments for those who disobeyed it.

It is also true that the concept of nationhood has a long history in China, and that the Chinese have been aware of the concept of the nation-state for centuries. However, it is important to note that different societies and cultures have developed their own forms of governance and organization over time, and it is not appropriate to make comparisons or judge one culture or society based on the standards of another.

It is also important to remember that the historical record is not always complete and accurate, and that different perspectives and interpretations of history exist. It is important to seek out multiple sources and consider different perspectives when studying history.

...the kerfluffle over the Hughes loan was symptomatic of a deeper Nixon problem--his poor relations with the press. At the time of the 1960 election, the Washington DC press corps consisted of about 100 reporters and special correspondents. Most of them were Democrats and unfriendly to Nixon on principle, and the feeling was mutual. Reporters often brought out the worst in him and his demeanor around them made him come off as stiff, cold, and not entirely human. A lot of Nixon's speeches were filled with the corny sentimentalism (cf. the Checkers speech) that endeared him to Main Street but which the gilded lily press corps found nauseating. "He was just so...icky, yucky, smarmy," said Mary McGrory of the Washington Post, while NYT correspondent Harrison Salisbury said that Nixon "gave off a terrible, sleazy quality." To be honest there were many moments during the campaign when he came off as exhausted, disheveled, and running on autopilot. While many Republicans had a point about their candidate not getting fair press coverage, the idea that the problem wasn't one-sided did not occur to them.

Yet it was less anti-Nixon partisanship the press corps were guilty of than excessive adulation of his opponent. Kennedy was everything Nixon was not--handsome, smooth, winsome, and eager to talk to the press, offering praise or criticism that never came off as rude. As the campaign wore on, many journalists came to almost be carried away with hero worship of the Massachusetts Senator, acting as if he was Moses leading America to the Promised Land, and believing in a sense of inevitability regarding his victory on Election Day.

>Georges Henri Joseph Édouard Lemaître (/ləˈmɛtrə/ lə-MET-rə; French: [ʒɔʁʒ ləmɛːtʁ] (listen); 17 July 1894 – 20 June 1966) was a Belgian Catholic priest, theoretical physicist, mathematician, astronomer, and professor of physics at the Catholic University of Louvain.[1] He was the first to theorize that the recession of nearby galaxies can be explained by an expanding universe,[2] which was observationally confirmed soon afterwards by Edwin Hubble.[3][4] He first derived "Hubble's law", now called the Hubble–Lemaître law by the IAU,[5][6] and published the first estimation of the Hubble constant in 1927, two years before Hubble's article.[7][8][3][4] Lemaître also proposed the "Big Bang theory" of the origin of the universe, calling it the "hypothesis of the primeval atom",[9] and later calling it "the beginning of the world".[10]

Hitler was literally a nobody. With no skills and no real social life. Hitler did not really exist, personally speaking, as a man, he was strictly a fantasy, a mythological placeholder for an expression of nation-wide desires and resentments. An event possible only in the specific constellation of the time and location at the very specific moment. Hitler is in effect a nothingness which spoke back consciously what the German nation thought unconsciously. Nobody with a real personality, a real self-determined entity could have accomplished that. Of course a Hitler could repeat, not in exactly the same way, but there is nothing that prevents something of that kind from happening in the future. Resentment, widespread poverty and chaos are breeding grounds for mass delusions and for radical fantasies. Hitler's specialty lies in the fact that we have perhaps never seen someone so capable of assuming every single national resentment and most vile fantasies as part of his personality. The capability lies in the fact that Hitler had no personality of his own, except for being that individual who took upon himself the yoke of the entire nation's evil fermentations. For a sovereign individual, something this radical is an impossibility, such taking up of mob hysteria is always paired with pragmatic detachment. Hitler certainly was pragmatic, but there was no real a "behind the mask" moment for the man, his "ingenuity" and "magic" lies in his and the mask being or becoming one and the same. Why is Utilitarianism associated with English culture? People had had ideas about what is pleasing being related to what is good since the Hellenistic era, namely the Cyrenaic school of philosophy and the Epicurean one.
Two of the most important direct predecessors of Utilitarianism were David Hume (who was born in Scotland) and Francis Hutcheson (who was born in Ireland).
Furthermore, neither England nor any other English-speaking country has even purely utilitarian in its customs and laws, as seen by looking at the 19th century Victorian era prudishness and the temperance movement, neither of which had the objective of maximizing pleasure or utility as their final end.
Therefore, although utilitarianism is a philosophical stance on ethics that was codified by Jeremy Bentham, a philosopher from England, it shouldn't be thought of as synonymous with English culture. Instead, it ought best to be thought of merely as one man's peculiar method of ethical decision-taking.
